The University trustees have
approved a budget of $228.6
million for the 1980-81 academic year. The budget includes
a planned deficit of $549,000.
The budgeted deficit for the
current year ending June 30,
1980 is $1.2 million, although a
smaller actual deficit is expected
by the time the books are
closed. A three-year budget plan
introduced last year called for a
approximately

$250,000 for the coming year,
and a return to financail equilibrium by 1981-82. An update of
the three-year plan has been
deferred until next fall because
of uncertianties in the national
economy, but a balanced budget
is still forcast for 1981-82.
"The current high rate of
inflation will make it impossible
for us to reduce the deficit in
the University's budget next
year as much as we had hoped"
explained Steven Muller, president of Johns Hopkins. "There
have been significant increases
in our revenues, but these,
unfortunately, have been more
than outstripped by rapidly
rising expenditures brought on
by double-digit inflation."
The $228.6 million budget
for next year represents an
increase of 13.5 percent above
the current budget of $201.5
million. It is worth noting,
however, that the 1971 budget
for the University was $96
million, and that next year's

budget in constant 1971 dollars
is only $106 million.
Of the total University
budget for 1980-81, $120.5
million represents general University funds, an increase of 16.8
percent over 1979-80. Expenditures in the form of sponsored
research and other externally
funded programs are expected to
reach $108.1 million, an increase
of 10 percent from the current
year.
On the expenditure side, the
largest items in the general funds
budget include instruction and
research($34.9 million); clinical
service activities ($23.1 million);
general services and administration ($ 16.8 million); operation
and plant maintenance ($16.1
million); student aid ($11.3
million) and libraries ($5.1 million).
The divisions of Homewood
Faculties, Arts and Sciences,
Engineering, Academic Centers
and Support Services, and the
Evening College have a combined 1980-81 budget of $55.4
million, including $39.9 million
from University general funds
and $15.5 million from sponsored research, training and other
programs.
Also included in the University's overall budget is the
Peabody Institute. Under terms
of the affiliation agreement
effective July 1, 1977, the
University is resposible for the
day-to-day operation of the

Institute, which maintains its
seperate corporate idenity. The
Peabody Institute's budget for
1980-81 is projected at $5.5
million.
The total budget for the
School of Advanced International Studies in Washington,
D.C. and the Bologna Center is
$4.9 million, of which $4.2
million is University general
funds and $.7 million is sponsored research and other projects.
Health Divisions Administration, Clinical Services, the
School of Medicine, and the
School of Hygiene and Public

Health have a combined budget
of $146.6 million for 1980-81,
including $58.9 million from
University general funds and
$87.7 million from sponsored
research, training and other
projects.
The principle sources of
revenue in the University's
general funds budget for
1980-81 are tuition and fees
($35.1 million); professional fees
earned by the medical faculty
($25 million); indirect cost recoveries ($23.7 million from
government and private sources);
endowment income ($10 mil-

lion); restricted gifts and grants
($1 million from government
sources and $6 million from
private sources); Maryland state
aid ($3.3 million); and temporary investment income ($2 million).
The Johns Hopkins Hospital
operates on a seperate budget.
The Applied Physics Laboratory
which operates primarily under
research and development contracts is expected to have
revenues and expenditures of
approximately $168.9 million in
1980-81.

To Quiz Applicants
BY ROGER S. BLUMENTHAL
Assistant
Director
of
Admission Sonny Mills announced earlier this week that his
office strongly encourages members of this year's graduating
class to join the Johns Hopkins
National Alumni Schools Committee. There will be a meeting
on May 13 at 7:00 in the Listening-Viewing Room for all interested seniors.
The Schools Committee has
been in existence for more than
20 years and has representatives
in 45 states and 7 foreign
countries. Approximately 20
members of the Class of '79
took part in the program this
year.
A member's primary responsibility is to interview four
or five applicants per year,
between January and March,
after that individual's application has been submitted. Subsequently, the Hopkins alumnus is
expected to write a short report
concerning his impressions of

the applicant.
All prospective freshmen
are still encouraged to visit
Homewood for an interview
with a member of the Admissions Office, but Director of
Admissions Jerry Schnydman
has found that an alumnus'
impressions of the applicant are
very
useful.
Eventually,
Schnydman would like to see
the alumni program expand into
something resembling that of
Princeton, Brown, Goergetown,
and Harvard.
Members of the Schools
Committee are sometimes asked
to attend a College Fair night in
their area, if it is convenient for
them to do so. It is felt that
recent graduates of Hopkins may
be able to give prospective
students a more complete description of what to expect if
they matriculate at Homewood.
In addition, all participating
alumni are notified whether or
not the people they have interviewed have been accepted by
the Admissions Office.

"Therapies," a play written and
directed by Chas Haller, will be presented
in the L/V Room on May 9 and 10 from
4 to 6 p.m.(admission will be free). This
play tells the story of how Cuffs (played
by Chris Rousseau), a gay high school
student, comes out of the closet only to
be subjected, at the insistance of his
parents, to unsavory psychotherapeutic
methods in an attempt to "cure" his
homosexuality. The result is a straight
marriage frought with complications.
The story unfolds through the flashbacks
of Jason (played by Doug Miller), a Gay
lawyer and Cuff's first lover.
"Cuffs" is a nickname (we never
learn his real name) that refers to the
handcuffs he wears at his belt. "S and M,
huh," Jason says, but Cuffs claims that
they are just something he has always
worn. They have a deeper meaning, one
that goes along with his fantasy about
cruising and being arrested by a vice-

The play adapts its major technique from Peter Shaffer's "Equus", in
which the present action is blended with
the action of a flashback - a device
appropriate for plays dealing with psychoanalysis and therapy. As one character recalls a scene to another character, it
comes alive around them, drawing the
story teller into its action. These scenes
are set within the larger framework of the
play, which is made up of the reenacted
flashbacks of Jason. As his audience, we
play the therapist - not the sort that
seeks to manipulate or analyze him,only
sympathetic listeners to his story.
Hailer's direction of these complicated
scenes is tight and the play is fast-paced
as a result.

low-key stage presence throughout the

experienced lawyer before the courtroom. Chris Rousseau, by contrast, has a

For those seniors who don't recall what the
weather was like on that Freshman Arrival Day nearly
four years ago, I shall refresh your memory Seventy-Five
degrees, low clouds, occasional drizzle, winds from the
southwest. Dreary as Hell.
I had awakened in the midst of the Pennsylvania
Dutch country, with pentangles on barn-gables flashing by
the window like rolling poker chips. According to the
conductor, we would be an hour late into Philly, where
everyone except me appeared to be getting off. Once
again, I repeated to myself the mantra from the Hopkins
Denver Alumni Meeting: "Remember to tell the cabbie
to take you to the Homewood Campus, or else when
you say 'Hopkins' he'll take you to the Med School,
which is in the ghetto and could be fatal. Oh, God."
I had spent most of the previous night in the
dome-car of The California Zephyr, sipping cokes and
watching the darkness roll past. I was fine, just fine,
until about 4 a.m., when we clattered over the Mississippi. At that point I suddenly lost it. The brave facade
crumbled like a stack of empty beer cans, and the true,
paralyzing, naked horror of LEAVING HOME hit
me.
I wanted my Mom.
I don't know if it was the combination of the
cokes inside me and the sight of Old Man River rolling
muddily below, or what, but at that moment, for the
first time in a dozen years, I wet my pants.
Trial by water. My baptism into the faith
of Higher Education, with fluid befitting a freshman.
Thus annointed, I arrived in the holy city of Baltimore, a
neophyte at the temple gates. Enlightenment would
come slowly, if at all.

nobody had the guts to be the first one through the
door. As it turned out, we could have saved ourselves
the trouble, for the first and second-floor halls were

"Therapies," a play written and
directed by Chas Haller, will be presented
in the L/V Room on May 9 and 10 from

play tells the story of how Cuffs (played
by Chris Rousseau), a gay high school
student, comes out of the closet only to
be subjected, at the insistance of his
parents, to unsavory psychotherapeutic
methods in an attempt to "cure" his
homosexuality. The result is a straight
marriage frought with complications.
The story unfolds through the flashbacks
of Jason (played by Doug Miller), a Gay
lawyer and Cuff's first lover.
"Cuffs" is a nickname (we never
learn his real name) that refers to the
handcuffs he wears at his belt. "S and M,
huh," Jason says, but Cuffs claims that
they are just something he has always
worn. They have a deeper meaning, one
that goes along with his fantasy about
cruising and being arrested by a vice-

which the present action is blended with
the action of a flashback - a device
appropriate for plays dealing with psychoanalysis and therapy. As one character recalls a scene to another character, it
comes alive around them, drawing the
story teller into its action. These scenes
are set within the larger framework of the
play, which is made up of the reenacted

play the therapist - not the sort that

sympathetic listeners to his story.
Hailer's direction of these complicated

as a result.

For those seniors who don't recall what the
weather was like on that Freshman Arrival Day nearly
four years ago, I shall refresh your memory Seventy-Five
degrees, low clouds, occasional drizzle, winds from the
southwest. Dreary as Hell.
I had awakened in the midst of the Pennsylvania
Dutch country, with pentangles on barn-gables flashing by
the window like rolling poker chips. According to the
conductor, we would be an hour late into Philly, where
everyone except me appeared to be getting off. Once
again, I repeated to myself the mantra from the Hopkins
Denver Alumni Meeting: "Remember to tell the cabbie
to take you to the Homewood Campus, or else when
you say 'Hopkins' he'll take you to the Med School,
which is in the ghetto and could be fatal. Oh, God."
I had spent most of the previous night in the
dome-car of The California Zephyr, sipping cokes and
watching the darkness roll past. I was fine, just fine,
until about 4 a.m., when we clattered over the Mississippi. At that point I suddenly lost it. The brave facade
crumbled like a stack of empty beer cans, and the true,
paralyzing, naked horror of LEAVING HOME hit
me.
I wanted my Mom.
I don't know if it was the combination of the
cokes inside me and the sight of Old Man River rolling
muddily below, or what, but at that moment, for the
first time in a dozen years, I wet my pants.
Trial by water. My baptism into the faith
of Higher Education, with fluid befitting a freshman.
Thus annointed, I arrived in the holy city of Baltimore, a
neophyte at the temple gates. Enlightenment would
come slowly, if at all.
